A. de 34 años de edad, hija de campesinos humildes, casada con Javier de 35 años de edad  es madre de 4 hijos, Ana Laura de 16, Marisol de 15, Honorio de 11 y Gustavo de 3 años cumplidos, solo estudian dos, ya que la mayor de ellos por falta de recursos no pudo ingresar este año a la escuela y le ayuda a su mamá en el pequeño negocio que tienen.
Martha lleva más de dos años en la venta de comida económica y esta actividad se ha convertido en su generador de ingresos ya que de las ganancias obtenidas las destina primero para la continuidad de su negocio, el pago de su crédito y el gasto escolar de sus hijos, esta es una manera también de apoyar a su esposo ya que con el salario de empleado no alcanza para suplir las necesidades de sus cuatro hijos y las de ellos, es por eso que ella decidió emprender este negocio, que aunque le queda cerca de su casa implica mucho trabajo y dedicación, ya que la elaboración de sus guisos la distinguen con toques únicos de sazón, en su negocio podemos encontrar en el día guisados como caldos, mole, adobo, y en las noches antojitos regionales como sopes, tacos, tostadas. 
Doña Martha se integro al grupo con la finalidad de obtener un crédito para invertir en su negocio, con el dinero que le prestaron compro algunos ingredientes como son, variedades de chiles, tomates, cebollas, verduras, frutas, hortalizas y semillas como frijol, arroz y maíz para la elaboración de tortillas, aceite, sal, azúcar y enlatados. Hasta hoy todo marcha  bien en su negocio y las ventas han estado muy bien y en la próxima temporada de vacaciones espera la visita de turistas y vacacionistas que pasan por este poblado.
Ella espera que su hija pueda seguir estudiando en este próximo ciclo escolar al igual que el negocio siga creciendo, y sus ventas no decaigan para así garantizar una buena condición de vida para su familia, le gustaría tener un restaurante en el cual no pague renta y pueda ofrecerles un respaldo sólido a su familia.
Lo que Martha nos puede agregar es que gracias a la colaboración de gente buena y noble ella ha podido mejorar su condición de vida y la de sus hijos, que  toda la gente se sumen a hacer algo bueno por los demás, les envía saludos a todos los que apoyan a KIVA y a Fundación Realidad, que DIOS los guarde.
Todos los nombre que integran al grupo “La aurora”, se enlistan a continuación así como sus actividades productivas.  

Francisca Vázquez. – Venta de antojitos
Maria Guadalupe E. Martínez.- Venta de quesos
Melissa García Zacarías.- Venta de calzado
Carmen Benita Martínez López.- Elaboración de quesos
Minerva Irma E. Martínez.-  Elaboración de quesos
Marta L. A..- Venta comida económica y antojitos
Eva R. Martínez.- Venta gelatinas y postres
Maria Apolinaria R..- Venta de pescados
Soledad Pérez M..- Elaboración de quesos
Cenobia Vásquez V..- Venta de frutas y verduras
José A. Rodríguez.- Venta de agua purificada
texts.en:
This group chose the name “La Aurora” (Dawn) because the group members liked the name because of its meaning.  For them the sensational phenomenon of dawn is linked to the hopes and expectations that each one of them has to arrive at a new day and just like interest is renewed so is the grace of living one more day in humans.  This is how the members explain the meaning of the name.  It is composed of 10 women and one man.  All are from San Miguel Tlacamama located 25 minutes from Pinotepa Nacional, Oaxaca.  It is known for the cheeses made in the area that are highly appreciated by locals.  Most of the people are associated with cheese making and also farm work.  The group meets in one of the member’s homes where cheese is made daily.  The group representative is Minerva Irma E. Martínez but in this case we will emphasize another group member

Martha L. A., 34, is a hardworking housewife.  She is the daughter of humble field workers and is married to Javier, 35.  She is the mother of four children: Ana Laura, 16, Marisol, 15, Honorio, 11 and Gustavo, 3.  Only two of them go to school because the oldest was unable to go to school this year due to lack of resources; she helps her mother in the small business they have.

Martha has been selling low-cost meals for over two years.  This activity has become her source of income.  Profits are directed primarily to provide continuity to the business, to repay her loan and to pay for her children’s educational expenses.  It is also a way to help her husband because his salary as an employee is insufficient to cover the needs of four children and themselves.  This is why she decided to go into this business which, although it is close to home, still implies much work and dedication because her meals stand out due to their special savory touches.  We can find her daily at her business cooking up soups, mole and adobo and in the evenings, regional snacks like sopes, tacos and tostadas.

Martha joined the group in order to obtain credit to invest in her business.  With money she was lent she bought some ingredients like: assorted chilies, tomatoes, onions, vegetables, fruits, leafy vegetables and grains like beans, rice, corn to make tortillas, oil, salt, sugar and canned goods.  To date everything in her business is running very well and she expects tourists and people on vacation to come through town during the next vacation period.

She hopes that her daughter will be able to restart her schooling next term and that the business continues to grow; that her sales don’t drop so that she can continue to guarantee a good living condition for her family.  She’d like to have a restaurant where she does not have to pay rent that would mean a solid support for her family.

What Martha can add now is that thanks to the collaboration from all the good and noble people she has been able to improve the living conditions of herself and her children.  She thanks the people who gather together to do good for others.  She sends greetings to everyone that supports Kiva and Fundación Realidad and asks God to keep them.

Following is a list of the names and activities of all the members of the “La Aurora” group:

Francisca Vázquez. – Fast food sales

Maria Guadalupe E. Martínez.- Cheese sales

Melissa García Zacarías.- Footwear sales

Carmen Benita Martínez López.- Cheese making

Minerva Irma E. Martínez.-  Cheese making

Marta L. A.. - Low-cost meals and fast food sales

Eva R. Martínez. - Gelatin and dessert sales

Maria Apolinaria R..- Fish sales

Soledad Pérez M..- Cheese making

Cenobia Vásquez V..- Fruit and vegetable sales

José A. Rodríguez.- Purified water sales

loans.use: To buy ingredients used in food preparation: chilies, tomatoes, onions, garlic, cheeses, oil, rice, beans, meats, fruits and vegetables; maize to make tortillas, salt and sugar.

loans.name: Kafundezi Basubuuzi Twegatte Group

texts.en: F. Bosco is the leader of Kafundesi group in Mubende. He is 26 years old and married with two children. For the past four years, he has owned a business in Lwanajo Kafundesi selling produce. He is able to make 100,000 UGX in monthly profits by selling to his loyal customers. Bosco says that he was a boda boda cyclist (bicycle taxi driver) before getting into the produce business. He was inspired to make the change by his friends, and he does not regret his decision. He is a hard-working man who needs a loan to be able to buy more matooke, cassava, and sweet potatoes for resale.

loans.use: To purchase matooke, cassava and sweet potatoes for resale

loans.name: Twekembe Kikooza Group-Mukono

texts.en:
Joyce N., 46, is happily married with six children who all go to school. 

She has been working in the rather lucrative charcoal sales business in and around Mukono town for the last decade. Charcoal is used by many households, not only in Mukono but all over Uganda, for cooking purposes. 

Joyce began this business under the auspices of her husband, who she says is a good-humored gentleman who has given her the latitude to freely go about her business, even if it means traveling long distances to sell her bags of charcoal. 

Joyce says what motivated her to work in this business were the high profits she was seeing her close friends making out of selling charcoal. Her profits total up to 80000 shillings a week. 

With this loan, Joyce says she is looking forward to purchasing more bags of charcoal to resell. She belongs to Twekembe Kikooza group-Mukono.

loans.use: To purchase more bags of charcoal to resell

loans.name: Marcely

texts.en:
30-year-old Marcely is from the town of Banga. She is married and has 2 young children. Marcely is a hard-working mother. She helps her husband maintain their rice farm. She also grows pigs for fattening and sale and she also runs a sari-sari store. Marcely wants only the best for her family.

Marcely joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marcely has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Marcely is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP which will be used to purchase seeds, feeds and additional merchandise to sell. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to save as a reserve for future emergencies.

loans.use: To purchase seeds, feeds and additional merchandise to sell

loans.name: Nuon's Group

texts.en:
Eight people are forming a village bank loan. They are located in Sdau Kanlaeng village in Kandal province. Mr. Nuon C., a married man B. in 1981, is the village bank president, selected by the other members. 

His wife, Mrs. Lat Sina, was B. in 1988 and works as a seamstress in a garment factory where she can earn a little salary to support her family. This couple has a child who is just 2 years old.  

Mr. Nuon C. earns his living by tailoring at home. In order to increase his income to improve the family’s condition, he would like to ask for a loan to buy more fabrics to resell and to support his business activities.

loans.use: To buy more fabrics

loans.name: Rebecca

texts.en:
Rebecca Q. is from the village of Brgy. Sto. Domingo West, Bambang, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 53 years old, married and has 4 adult-aged children. Rebecca owns and operates a business providing tricycle transport services. Rebecca has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month from it.

In 2010, Rebecca joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rebecca has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from ASKI, which was used to purchase tires and other accessories. Rebecca is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to repair an existing vehicle for better service. This will be the 2nd loan taken out by Rebecca from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's general living conditions.

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to repair a vehicle for better service

location.town: Brgy. Sto.Domingo West, Bambang, Nueva Vizcaya

loans.name: Gad

texts.en:
Gad G. is 42 years old and is married with five children. He also takes care of two other children. 

For eight years, he has worked as a driver to transport people's goods to their places. He works from 6 a.m. until 7 p.m. every day and he currently employs one person to help him.

Gad has requested a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company in order to buy new tires for his vehicle. He hopes to earn more profits. With these profits he expects to reinvest in his transportation business.

loans.use: to buy new tires for his vehicle

loans.name: Batsuren

texts.en:
Batsuren is 36 years old and lives with her husband and two children in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. They live together in a studio apartment which they bought under leasing contract. Her two sons, 2 and 16 years old, are attending local schools. 

Batsuren has operated a spare parts retail business since 2004 by renting a stall at “Auto Plaza”, the biggest spare parts market in city. Her husband, Erkhembayar, works with her as a salesperson. She buys brand new spare parts from Beijing, the capital city of China, and sells them on a profit. She also sells secondhand spare parts, which she collects, fixes and replenishes. She has her own customers and her products are in good demand. 

She is a very hardworking and energetic person. At this time she is working hard to be able to send her children all the way through college. She is requesting a loan to purchase more spare parts from Beijing.

loans.use: to buy more spare parts from China

loans.name: Zosima

texts.en: Zosima is married with five children. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur. Zosima is 60 years old. She has a charcoal sales business in the Philippines. Zosima has been in this business for 15 years. Zosima requested a 10,000 Philippine peso (PHP) loan through NWTF to purchase more stock to sell. In the future, Zosima would like to repair and renovate her family home.

loans.use: to purchase more stock to sell.

loans.name: Delma

texts.en:
Delma C. is from the village of Ninoy Aquino, Kalilangan, Bukidnon. She is 50 years old. Delma is married and has three adult children. 

To make a living, Delma owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling canned goods, snack foods, detergents, shampoo, soap and biscuits in the local community. Delma has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Delma joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and living situation. Delma has successfully repaid a previous loan of 14,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and for working capital. 

Delma is requesting a new loan of 17,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional canned goods, snack foods and detergents. This will be the fifth loan taken out by Delma from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:
HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional canned goods, snack foods and detergents.

loans.name: Luis Alberto

texts.es:
Alberto tiene 49 años de edad, es soltero con 02 hijos mayores de edad los cuales son independientes. Alberto vive en casa de su madre. Su domicilio esta ubicado en Ciudad del Chofer, una zona urbana de la cuidad de Chiclayo.

Alberto se dedica a la venta de productos de higiene personal, como shampus, talco y desodorante, los cuales los compra al por mayor en Lima y los vende a comerciantes minoristas del Mercado Modelo. Alberto  reparte al contado y al crédito su mercadería.  Posee más de 05 años de antigüedad en el rubro, en el cual ha ganado experiencia y captado buen numero de clientes fidelizados con su servicio y sus productos.

Alberto esta solicitando un crédito a Edpyme Alternativa de S/. 2,400.00  para destinarlo a una inversión más grande para su negocio. Tiene pensado comprar más mercadería ya que como se está  haciendo mas conocido tiene mayores pedidos por nuevos clientes. Es su deseo abastecer a todos  y seguir creciendo como distribuidor.

Alberto es un cliente conocido por Edpyme Alternativa, por lo cual cuenta con muy buenas referencias de su persona.
texts.en:
Alberto, age 49, is single and has two adult children who are independent.  He lives with his mother in Ciudad del Chofer, an urban area in the city of Chiclayo.

Alberto sells personal hygiene products such as shampoo, talcum powder, and deodorant which he buys wholesale in Lima and then sells to retailers in the Modelo Market.  He sells on both credit and cash bases.  He has been in business for five years and has gained experience as well as many loyal customers.

He is requesting a loan in the amount of 2,400 PEN that he plans to invest mainly in his business.  He will use it to buy more merchandise because his customers are starting to place larger orders.  His wish is to be able to fill all orders and grow as a distributor.

Alberto is a known customer of Edpyme Alternative and has good personal references.

loans.use: To buy merchandise for his business

loans.name: Melca

texts.en:
Melca lives in the village of Guanzon Tuto St., Gingoog City. She is 42 years old, married and has one school-aged child. For the last five years, she has made a living by selling beauty and home cleaning products and earns about 5,000 PHP a month from her work.

In 2010, Melca joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her life and ability to engage in business. She has successfully repaid a loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI and is applying for a new one to buy additional items to sell to her customers. She plans to use the additional income made possible by this loan to continue expanding her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to buy additional items to sell to her customers.

location.town: Guanzon Tuto St., Gingoog City, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Kisarawe Group

texts.en:
Fatuma, who is in her mid 30s, is married and has five children who go to school. 

She has had a business of selling new clothes from door to door for four years now. She works from 11:00 a.m. to 2:00 p.m. daily and is able to make a small monthly profit.

This will be Fatuma’s third loan from  Tujijenge Tanzania. She used the previous loans to pay school fees and increase the clothes stock and has repaid all her loans successfully. She hopes for a loan to buy more clothes for resale. Her dream is to one day finish building her house.

Fatuma will share this loan with her loan group, “Kisarawe,” which has a total of 19 members who will hold each other accountable in paying back their loans.

loans.use: To buy more clothes to sell.

loans.name: Zenatu

texts.en: Zenatu is married and has three children. Her husband is a driver. She has received a senior high education. Zenatu sells provisions such as tissue paper, fruit juice, canned fish, meat, toothpaste and other items at Abura near Nyame Bekyere. She has been doing this business for five years. Zenatu uses her income to assist her husband in the payment of school fees and utility bills. Zenatu will use the loan to purchase more provisions. With the new profits from her expanded business, Zenatu plans to reinvest her additional profit.

loans.use: to purchase more provisions to sell.

loans.name: Antero German

texts.es:
El socio pertenece al banco comunal “SUMAC  AYLLU”; el banco se encuentra ubicado en el Distrito de Huanchac en la Provincia de Cusco y Departamento de Cusco.

El socio Antero tiene 39 años de edad, el socio es conviviente, El socio tiene 3 hijos de 14, 4 y 3 meses de edad; El socio es comerciante minorista, el socio tiene una tienda de venta de todo tipo de licores y una tienda en general para lo cual el socio desea implementar y comprar en especial cajas de licores de fresa, mango, durazno, y vinos, whisky. El socio solicita el préstamo para invertir en la compra de licores para implementar su negocio.

La socia agradece el apoyo que se le otorgara y así mismo se compromete a cumplir de manera disciplinada con los pagos de las cuotas.
texts.en:
Antero is a member of the "Sumac Ayllu" community bank which is located in Huanchac district, in Cusco province and department.

Antero is 39 years old and lives with his partner.  He has three children aged 14, 4 and 3 months.  He is a salesman and has a store selling all kinds of liquor.  He also has a general store.  Antero would like to stock his business.  In particular he would like to buy cases of strawberry, mango and peach liquor; wine and whisky.  He is requesting this loan to buy liquor to stock his business.

Antero is grateful for the support that he is being given and pledges to make his repayments in a disciplined manner.

loans.use: to invest in buying liquor to stock his business

loans.name: Manuel

texts.pt:
Nasceu no Distrito de Namaacha  Provincia de Maputo tem 33 anos de idade vive maritalmente fez a 6ª classe não continuou devido a falta de condições financeiras, é pai de 1 filha de 12 anos que vai a Escola. Vive numa casa alugada e sustenta seu irmão que vive com ele em sua casa. 

 Começa a trabalhar no Hotel Xisaka como Tecnico de Manutenção de Maguinas, consegue fixar sua propria casa. Trabalha  ha mais de 6 anos. Aufere por mês 3.500.00mt, que aplica nas dispesas da casa e da sua obra. Para além do trabalho nos seus tempos livres ele tem ido a fronteira da swazilandia onde são solicitados para transportar carros que vem da Africa do Sul( carros de dubai) ate a capital Maputo,  ganhando por viagem 500.00mt. 

Este é o quinto empréstimo no valor de 25.000.00mt com o qual pretende comprar material de construção( cimento, areia, barrotes portas e mais) para dar continuidade da sua obra. Os anteriores de 3.500.00mt e 5.000.00mt foram usados para tirar a carta de condução, de  15.000.00 e 20.000.00mt para construção da sua casa. esta confiante que vai reembolsar antes do tempo previsto e pedir outro credito para construção do murro de vedação.
texts.en:
He was born in the Namaacha district in the Maputo province.  He is 33-years-old, married, and completed six years of schooling but didn’t continue because there wasn’t enough money.  He has one daughter who is 12-years-old and who goes to school.  He lives in a rented house and maintains his brother who lives with him in his house.

He began to work in the Xisaka Hotel as a machine maintenance technician and was able to get his own house.  He has worked there for more than six years.  He earns 3,500 meticais (Mozambique currency) monthly which he uses for household expenses and construction costs.  In addition to work, in his free time he goes to the border with Swaziland where people are needed to transport cars that come from South Americ (cars from Dubai) to the capital, Maputo, earning 500 meticais per trip.

This is his fifth loan and it is in the amount of 25,000 meticais with which he intends to buy construction materials (cement, sand, door beams, and more) to continue working on his house project.  The previous loans of 3,500 and 5,000 meticais were used to get a driver’s license and those for 15,000 and 20,000 meticais were for construction work on his house.  He is confident that he will repay the loan before the set time and request another to build a fence.

loans.use: to buy building materials (cement, sand, door beams and more).

loans.name: Patrick

texts.en:
The partiality to farming is like a byword in most of western Uganda. Most people in Western Uganda are very exhilarated about farming and hold it in high regard. The spirit and love for farming is handed down from past generations in these areas. If one does not end up farming, they will end up engaging in the other popular economic activities like raising goats and cattle 

A 35-year-old father of four, Patrick says for his case, he set forth in this business four years ago in Rukungiri.  Not so long, one may say, but he says he is already enjoying the experience of engaging in this business and he is already seeing better days on the horizon for his business. He has been basking in the glow of good business, principally after selling most of the crops he grows like bananas and cassava. The good spells he has enjoyed however, do not mean he has not bore witness to adversity. He says during some particular dry seasons, his business suffers bad harvests and consequently, he is not able to sell most of his harvests at good competitive market prices. This, at length, adversely affects his financial standing. Monthly, this business generates sales revenue to the tune of Ugandan shillings 150,000 and he says with this Kiva loan he is going to purchase hoes, pangas and high-grade manure to apply on his farms.

loans.use: to purchase hoes, pangas and high-grade manure

loans.name: Mwanajuma

texts.en:
Mwanajuma is a married woman with four children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past four years, she has operated a fish-selling business, selling at the market to her neighbors and passersby. She faces a major challenge in the high cost of transporting fish to her place of operation. Her major dream is to improve her living standards in the future.

With the 10,000 Kenyan shillings, she wants to purchase sacks of fish for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase sacks of fish for resale.

loans.name: Maria

texts.es: María  tiene 38 años, es separada y vive en compañía de sus 2 hijos en casa de sus suegros. Desde hace 7 años se dedica a la ganadería y la agricultura, asimismo cultiva pastos para alimentar a sus animales y también siembra maíz, producto que comercializa de manera periódica. Pero la fuente de ingresos más importante está en la venta de diaria de leche, extraída de las 3 vacas que posee. Por el tiempo de experiencia que tiene trabajando en esta actividad  se ha dado cuenta que es muy importante  atender en buenas condiciones a sus animales sobre todo sus vacas porque de ello depende que puedan producir la leche necesaria que vende. Con el tiempo ha implementado su establo, sin embargo le es muy necesario mejorar la infraestructura de su establo porque se acerca la época de invierno y es donde más dificultades se presentan si se trata de mantener limpio su establo. Por tal motivo decidió buscar opciones de financiamiento que le permita concretar sus planes en mente, es en ahí que decidió trabajar con MFP ya que vio que es una buena opción cuyas cuotas están a su alcance. Y con el dinero que reciba comprará arena y bolsas de cemento, también contratará mano de obra que le servirá para colocar piso de concreto en su estalo que mejorará considerablemente la atención de sus animales.
texts.en:
María is 38 years old; she is separated and lives with her two children in her in-laws' house.  For the last seven years, she has been working with livestock and agriculture.  She also grows pastureland for feeding her animals, and in addition grows corn, a product that she sells periodically.  However, her most important source of income is selling dairy milk, obtained from her three cows.

During the time that she has been doing this work, she has found that it is very important to provide good conditions for her animals, especially her cows as she depends on them to be able to produce the milk she needs to sell.  Over time, she has built a cowshed.  However, it is now very necessary for her to improve the infrastructure of the cowshed, because she is coming up to the winter season, and this poses many difficulties if she is to keep the cowshed clean.  It is for this reason that she decided to look for financing options that will allow her to put her plans into practice, and so she decided to work with MFP as she saw it was a good option with repayments that were within her reach.  

With the money that she is receiving, she will buy sand and bags of cement.  She will also hire workmen to put down a concrete floor in her cowshed, which will considerably improve the care of her animals.

loans.use: to buy sand, cement and hire workmen to put a floor in her cowshed.

loans.name: Ricardo

texts.en:
“Keep your dreams alive. Understand to achieve anything requires faith and belief in yourself, vision, hard work, determination, and dedication. Remember all things are possible for those who believe,” is an expression of Ricardo, a 46-year-old businessman. He is an owner of a variety store operating successfully for 12 years and earning a PHP 10,000 every month.

An optimistic person like Ricardo provides further positive results in every inch of his work. He keeps on dreaming and wishes to achieve his dream through a loan of PHP 10,000 as additional working capital. This will be used to buy supplementary stock such as soft drinks for his variety store. He hopes this would be a big contribution to achieve success.

He hopes for every success in his operation to help more people.

loans.use: to buy supplementary stock such as soft drinks in his variety store

loans.name: Kodjo Mensah

texts.fr:
Kodjo Mensah est un homme âgé de 33ans. Il est marié å une revendeuse de bouillie. Il a 02 enfants. 
Kodjo Mensah travaille comme mécanicien d’automobile et vendeur de pièces détachées depuis 2001. Il répare toutes sortes de voiture dans son garage à Bè-Kpota. Il achète les pièces détachées au port autonome de Lomé et au Ghana.
Kodjo Mensah a requis son premier cycle de prêt à  WAGES afin d’acheter des moteurs de voiture. 
Dans les prochaines années, Kodjo Mensah voudrait accroître son  activité et avoir beaucoup d’apprentis mécaniciens. Il dit qu’avec les profits, Il prévoit acheter unterrain et mettre ses enfants à l’aise.
texts.en:
Kodjo Mensah is a 33-year-old man who is married to a woman who sells porridge. He has two children and has been working as an automobile mechanic and a seller of spare parts since 2001. He repairs all kinds of  cars in his garage in Bè-Kpota. He buys spare parts at the Autonomous Port of  Lomé and from Ghana. 

Kodjo Mensah has requested his first loan cycle at WAGES to buy motors for cars. In the next few years, he would like to grow his business and to have many apprentice mechanics. 

With the profits, he says he plans to buy a plot of land and provide his children with a comfortable life.

loans.use: to buy motors for cars

loans.name: Phoebe

texts.en: Phoebe is a businesswoman who is 45 years old. She is married and blessed with two children, both in school. For the last two years, she has been managing a retail shop to bring up her family. She is also employed as a teacher. In the next five years, she wants to expand her business into a wholesale business. She is requesting a loan of 20,000 Kenya shillings to buy sugar and maize flour.

loans.use: To buy sugar and maize flour to sell

loans.name: Juan

texts.es: El señor Juan es chofer; trabaja repartiendo distintos productos por menor a  tiendas en la ciudad de La Paz. El crédito lo requiere para el mantenimiento de su movilidad, específicamente para  reparar el motor de su vehiculo. Esta es la única actividad que le ayuda a cubrir los gastos de su familia. Vive en casa propia la misma queda ubicada en la zona de Tembladerani en la Ciudad de La Paz; es casado y tiene 3 hijos. Es la primera vez que Juan obtiene un crédito.
texts.en: Juan is a driver; her works delivering various retail products to stores in the city of La Paz.  He needs the loan to service his vehicle, specifically for engine repairs.  This is the only activity he has to help cover family expenses.  He lives in his own house located in the city of La Paz’s Temladerani zone.  He’s married and has three children.  This is the first time Juan’s gotten a loan.

loans.use: to service his delivery truck.

loans.name: Sari Makmur Group

texts.en:
The Sari Makmur Group  and it's members received the same amount of loan as the last time.

Ni Komang is using this loan to buy three superior piglets. She decided to choose the superior quality piglets because she receives a high price when she sells them and it's easier to find a big buyer. She hopes the business can run smoothly and give her enough profit to support her life.

loans.use: To buy three superior piglets

loans.name: Fe

texts.en:
Fe is 55 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with four children. 

Fe has a pigpen that sells matured and grown pigs. She has had this business for ten years. She has requested a loan for PHP 5,000 to buy feed for the pigs.

Fe is a new member of HSPFI.  In the future, Fe hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy animal feed for her pigs.

loans.name: 0402017-Liên Minh-Hoằng Trường Hoang Hoa Group

texts.en:
Thư operates a food stall where she sells fish. She is requesting a loan to maintain her fishing boat to catch fish to sell. Thư has been involved in this business for more than 10 years.

Thư is 47 years old and is married with three children. She lives and works in Hoang Hoa district, a rural area in the Thanh Hoa province, with one dependent.

She is the leader of a five-member group, the 0402017-Liên Minh-Hoằng Trường Hoang Hoa solidarity group. In 2010, Thư joined the Fund for Thanh Hoa Poor Women to improve her business. Thư has successfully repaid two loans from the Fund for Thanh Hoa Poor Women.

One of the most critical business difficulties that concerns her is the lack of capital. With her business profit, Thư hopes to maintain a successful business, make enough money to provide for her kids, and be healthy and happy.

loans.use: to maintain her fishing boat to catch fish to sell.

loans.name: José Werner

texts.es: José Werner de 46 años de edad, vive  en casa familiar junto con su esposa e hijo. José es muy trabajador, responsable y dedicado. Para José lo más importante es su familia y es por ella que trabaja duramente para poder llevar el pan de cada día al hogar. Él se dedica a la venta de detergentes como: lejía, desinfectante, suavizador, etc. Tiene muchos años de dedicarse al negocio por lo que ya cuenta con muchos clientes fijos. Además muchas personas la prefieren ya que él siempre está pendiente de mantener satisfechos a los clientes ya que sabe que todo depende de ellos. Su sueño es ver florecer su negocio con el fin de mejorar su calidad de vida y la de su familia. Es por esta razón que solicita este crédito a INTEGRAL para invertir en su negocio en la compra variedad de detergentes como: lejía, desinfectante, suavizador, etc. de tal manera que pueda cubrir una mayor demanda que le permita mejorar sus niveles de venta como de ingresos y por consecuencia mejorar su calidad de vida y la de su familia.
texts.en: José Werner, age 46, lives with his wife and their son in the family home. The most important thing in José's life is his family, and it is for them that he works hard to bring home the daily bread. He sells detergents, including bleach, disinfectant, fabric softener, etc. He has been running this business for many years and has many regular clients. Many people prefer to buy from him because he makes sure his customers are satisfied - he knows, after all, that the business depends on them. His dream is to see his business grow and blossom, with the aim of improving his family's quality of life. For this reason, he is seeking a loan with INTEGRAL to invest in the business by buying a variety of detergents, so that he can expand and increase his sales, his income, and ultimately his family's standard of living.

loans.use: To buy bleach, disinfectant, fabric softener, etc

loans.name: Maribeth

texts.en:
This is Maribeth, 28, resident of Dasmarinas Cavite, Philippines. She is married to Rodelito, a seaman, and is the mother of three children, two of whom are in grade school. She, together with her children, manages their household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income to cover her everyday expenses.  

Maribeth operates a buy-and-sell business. What she basically does is buy beauty products merchandise from wholesalers, sell them by the piece with a profit. Customers are attracted to buy due to the low selling prices and the many options they are offered. Her regular customers are her neighbours and the local community.  She earns a minimum of 500 Philippine Pesos (PHP) in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php15,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more quantities and varieties of beauty products to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her income as she expands her business. 

Maribeth dreams to be able to give all her children a high quality education through all her hard work in her business. She also dreams to have her own shop in a commercial place. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies. 
 
* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for additional stocks of items and beauty products needed in her business.

loans.name: Modi

texts.en: Modi is a 38-year-old married woman with four children, all of whom are in school. She has had a fish selling business in Yambio, South Sudan for two years. Modi is requesting this loan through BRAC South Sudan to purchase fish. She will use her extra income from this loan to pay her children's school fees.

loans.use: to purchase fish for sale.

loans.name: Gerardo

texts.es:
Gerardo, solicita un nuevo préstamo por el motivo que ya es tiempo de recoger su cosecha y pagar mano de obra con el propósito de tenerla ya en casa, venderla y comprara ganado para crecerlos,  para obtener otros ingresos el cual le ayudara a su familia.
Los financiamientos anteriores le ayudaron porque obtuvo los fertilizantes necesarios para sus cosechas y este año fueron abundantes gracias al apoyo de nuestra institución que le brindo el apoyo necesario.
texts.en: Gerardo is requesting a new loan because it is time to gather in his harvest and he needs to pay laborers so that he can have it ready, sell it and buy cattle to raise.  This will enable him to obtain more income which will help his family.  His previous loans helped him to obtain the fertilizers he needed for his crops and this year they were abundant thanks to the support of our institution which gave him the support he needed.

loans.use: to pay laborers to gather his harvest

loans.name: Tukole Kakindo Group

texts.en:
Christine is a member of Tukole Kakindo group, where each member guarantees the other in accessing a loan. She is hardworking and a married mother of six children. She owns a clothing business and she has been operating it for 5 years now.

She faces business challenges of high fuel costs and price fluctuations which she believes is cutting across and all her group members are facing the same challenges as well. Her family goal is to educate her children and build a permanent house, and her business goal is to expand to new markets. Christine needs the loan facility to buy clothes to sell.

loans.use: to buy clothes to sell

loans.name: Patricia

texts.en: Patricia is a 24-year-old married woman with 2 children. She has a small plantation and has been growing taro and bananas to earn a living for 4 years. She has requested a loan to buy a wheelbarrow, shovels, fertilizers, and crops. She has been a member of SPBD since 2009. With her profits, Patricia hopes to pay for her family's weekly expenses.

loans.use: buy a wheelbarrow, shovels, fertilizers,..

loans.name: Lucille

texts.en: Lucille  is 34 years old, married, and has five  children. Her husband is a laborer  and she helps with a business in a farm growing vegetables. Lucille also manages a small backyard piggery. She grows pigs for fattening and sells them to the market. Lucille is requesting a loan which she will use to purchase pig feed, piglets and pesticides.  Lucille, hopes for her children to be successful in the future.

loans.use: to buy  pig feed, piglets and pesticides

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary Warua is 62 years old, married with 6 children, 2 of them still live with her and provides every thing.

Mary has been selling used clothes for the last seven years. The business has been performing very well because these items are not only cheap but also affordable by many people. This gives her a high profit margin and keeps her pushing forward. She also grows coffee on a small scale and keeps a dairy cow. There is improvement in milk prices and this is encouraging her to buy another cow, which can give about 20 litres per day.

loans.use: She would like to buy a dairy cow that can give her 20 litres per day.

loans.name: Segundo

texts.en:
Segundo has 23 years of experience in his field. He learned the business when he was very young, while helping his father. His business is located on the street corner outside of his house. He sells fish, pork and beef. He tends to his business every day of the week in 2 shifts, morning and afternoon. Aside from his fish and meat business, Segundo also sell household items when business is slow. His work has allowed him to buy his house.

He needs the loan to buy a table on which to display his products and to buy a freezer.

Segundo was born in Los Ríos. He is 42 years old with 4 children, all of whom are still in school. His wife helps him in the business when he has to go out. She also has her own business selling chicken in a market. They have both been able to move their businesses ahead through their perseverance and sense of responsibility. With their earnings they bought a cement house. Their greatest satisfaction is that their children are in school and are taking advantage of the opportunity to study. Their aspiration is to strengthen their businesses since they are the only source of income for the family.

Translated by Erin Corcoran, Kiva volunteer.

Segundo tiene una experiencia de 23 años en esta actividad. Aprendió con su padre desde joven cuando lo ayudaba. Él esta ubicado en la esquina de su casa y vende pescado, carne de res y cerdo. Todos los días de la semana atiende en 2 jornadas por la mañana y al atardecer. Segundo a parte de su negocio, él también se ha dedicado a vender artículos para el hogar cuando esta bajo su negocio. Su trabajo le ha permitido tener obtener su casa.

Él necesita el préstamo para comprar una mesa y exhibir su producto, y abonar para un congelador.

Segundo nació en Los Ríos. Tiene 42 años. Con 4 hijos que están en la escuela y colegio. Su esposa le ayuda en el negocio cuando él tiene que salir. Ella también tiene su propio negocio de venta de pollo en un mercado. Ambos han podido salir adelante en sus negocios por su perseverancia y responsabilidad que le han puesto. Con los ingresos generados se compraron su casa de cemento y su satisfacción más grande es que sus hijos estudian y están aprovechando. Su aspiración es fortalecer el negocio por que son sus únicas fuentes de ingresos.

loans.use: Make improvements to the stand where he sells his products and buy a freezer.

loans.name: Sara

texts.en: Sara T. is a hard-working fifty-three year old womanwith seven children. Her husband and all the children work together to tend the taro plantation.  Taro is a staple of the Samoan diet, and there is always demand for it at the local markets.  The family can bring in up to ST 100 per day (approximately USD 40) with their taro crop sales.  This is the main income source for this large family, and Sara feels that it is a sustainable income that they can grow with hard work.  She says that if the family concentrates on working hard, the money will come and will be enough to meet their needs.  She is applying for a loan to buy some basic gardening equipment like shovels, knives and gloves to help make their work more productive.

loans.use: :  Buy equipment:  shovels, knives, gloves

loans.name: Nazkhanim

texts.en: Nazkhanim M. opened her small shop using a loan she borrowed from Aqroinvest CU in 1996. Her family has four members, and to cover family needs she is going to broaden her store and open a food section. She has applied for a loan of $1,200 USD to broaden and repair her store.

loans.use: To broaden her store by opening a food section

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase of more medicine and display case

loans.name: Safina

texts.en:
Safina is a single 32-year old woman caring for her three children and her grandmother. She has a small vegetable and fruit stand at the roadside market in the Mutundwe Village outside of Kampala. She has had the stand for four years and has been a member of her lending group for four years.

Her stand is located in a busy location where the “matatoo” stops, so her setup is convenient for passers-by and people getting in and out of the matatoo. Most matatoo's are converted Toyota Vans that can seat 14 passengers.

She sells a variety of items, including bananas, sugar cane, ground nuts, and carrots. She also sells ebumba, clay that is baked and sold for nausea, (it tastes like baked clay with tiny stones), bitter berries for hypertension, and dried minnow-sized fish which is mixed with ground nut paste to make a sauce eaten with fruit. She will use her loan to buy more variety for her fruit stand and to help pay school fees for her children.

loans.use: Safina will use her loan to buy more bananas, sugar cane, and ground nuts for her stand and to pay school fees for her children

loans.name: Thavy

texts.en:
Mrs. Thavy H. married in 1986 and has two sons. She learned to weave silk from her aunt in 2000 and began her silk production in the same year. In 2003 she trained her husband to weave silk as well. He used to be in the military. He has assisted Thavy in the business since 2003. She now wants to set up one more loom for her husband so that they can expand their silk production business. Currently, only one son is studying at the local school. Their other son is severely ill and stays at home.

Mrs. H. is requesting a loan from MAXIMA for the first time in the amount of US$ 1,000. She will use this loan to purchase silk materials and sewing thread, to pay fees for selecting and preparing silk on the looms, and to set up another loom for her husband.

loans.use: Purchasing silk materials and sewing thread; fees for selecting and preparing silk on the looms and setting up another loom.

loans.name: Janet's Group

texts.en:
Janet K. sell poultry to customers. With this loan, Janet wants to buy more poultry birds to satisfy her customers.

Background on BRAC and BRAC Uganda

BRAC (Building Resources Across Communities) is a development organization that began operations in Bangladesh as a small-scale relief and rehabilitation project in 1972 to help the country overcome the devastation and trauma of the liberation war and focused on resettling refugees returning from India. Today, BRAC has emerged as an independent, virtually self-financed paradigm in sustainable human development. It is one of the largest Southern development organizations employing over 100,000 people, 61% of which are women, and working with the twin objectives of poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor. Diagnosing poverty in human terms and recognizing its multifaceted nature, BRAC approaches poverty alleviation with a holistic approach.

The successes of BRAC in the international development arena have stimulated a series of discussions, both with African delegations, who have visited BRAC programs, and with donors who work in Asia and Africa. Both the African countries and the donors have encouraged BRAC to join the development campaign in Africa to achieve the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs) and more recently to join the campaign of “ending poverty”, which is an area where Africa represents the greatest global challenge.

In Uganda, BRAC registered as a Non Government Organization (NGO) in January 2006 to undertake programs in Education, Health, Water & Sanitation, Agriculture & Livestock and Microfinance. The Microfinance and Education are the pioneer programs launched in Uganda and, as of July 2007, had served 21,273 borrowers and enrolled 1,155 adolescents in its education program.

loans.use: To add more birds to her business

loans.name: Jamila

texts.en:
Mambo from Mwanza, Tanzania! This is 30-year-old Jamila Zaidi. She is married with three children, aged 5, 7, and 10. In 2003 Jamila established a business selling used clothing and soap, and now requires a loan of $350 in order to purchase additional stock in bulk.

Second-hand clothes journey across the oceans from America and Europe, and are then washed, ironed and sold in bulk by wholesalers in Dar es Salaam and other major towns and cities in Tanzania to retailers who then re-wash and re-iron them for sale on the streets, in shops, and people's homes and gardens. These clothes are becoming increasingly popular, especially amongst the younger generation, because they are so cheap and because of the general appeal of anything western or modern. Many people argue that the popularity of the West’s cast-offs is damaging the local cloth and garment industry. There are many people who still appreciate the beauty of traditional Tanzanian dress; however the growing market in used clothing and its importance to many micro-entrepreneurs cannot be denied.

loans.use: To purchase additional stocks of used clothing and soap in bulk.

loans.name: Komilahon

texts.en: Komilahon N. is 22 years old and she lives in the Asht region of Tajikistan. She works in a collective farm but because it is seasonal, she also works selling perfumes. She is able to get a good assortment from direct suppliers and sells them for prices lower than those in the bazaar. Now Mrs. N. is applying to KIVA for a loan of $625.00 to develop her business.

loans.use: For developing her existing business

loans.name: Isatu

texts.en:
Isatu is 28 years old and married with one child. She is dropped out of school, but has business skills and a vision for both her business and her child’s future.

She would like to buy an additional refrigerator and increase her inventory so that she can offer a larger selection of drinks. This will allow her to meet customer demand during the long, hot, dry season.

loans.use: To purchase a refrigerator and a larger selection of drinks

loans.name: Edith

texts.en:
Edith N. is a baker and sells bread. She is married and has three children. She needs money to invest in her business because the price of flour has gone up.

She is asking for $125 as additional capital to buy more materials for her bakery.

loans.use: To buy more materials for her bakery

loans.name: Sophal

texts.en:
Mrs. Sophal K. is a farmer in the Beng Village of Kampong Speu Province. She is a 39-year-old mother of four children: one child attends state school, another child stays at home to assist her in the field, and the other two children are too young to work or study. Her husband, Mr. Von Yon (pictured on the left), is a farmer and a teacher.

As a result, the family lives in poor conditions because all of the family members have small business activities and, on the whole, they are not able to generate much income. Additionally, they live in an old house, and they do not even have enough money to build a toilet. Therefore, Mrs. Sophal K. is seeking a loan to enable them to build a toilet for her family.

loans.use: To improve her family's standard of living by building a toilet in their house.

loans.name: Josephine

texts.fr:
Mrs. Josephine O., a widow, was born around 1937 in Cotonou in Littoral County in the south of Benin. Having proved her excellence in the realm of arts and crafts since around 1971, she was chosen to be honored by the Ministry of Handicrafts and Tourism. She purchases the shells she uses to make her works of art in Togo, the country situated to the west of Benin. Mrs. O. has discovered a new market: the sale of her art works in hotels. Thus, she is experiencing some financial difficulty in acquiring the raw materials for her creations, and this is the reason why she is presently requesting her second loan from Alidé.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva volunteer

Dame O. Josephine est une veuve née vers 1937 à COTONOU dans le département du Littoral au sud du BENIN. Ayant fait ses preuves dans le domaine de l'artisanat depuis les années 1971, elle a bénéficié d'un tableau d'honneur qui lui a été décerné par le Ministère de l' Artisanat et du Tourisme. Elle achète du TOGO, pays situé à l'ouest du BENIN, des coquilles dont elle se sert pour la conception des tableaux d'art. Dame O. Josephine a découvert un nouveau marché: la vente de ses œuvres dans les hôtels. Ainsi, pour ses réalisations, elle éprouve quelques difficultés financières pour s'approvisionner, raison pour laquelle elle vient solliciter son deuxième crédit à ALIDé.

loans.use:
purchase of 50 piles of shells, 3 tins of varnish, and 10 meters of poplin

Achat de 50 tas de coquilles, de 3 boîtes de vernis et de 10 mètres de popeline.

loans.name: Saophai

texts.en:
Mrs. Saophai P. lives in Kork Village in Kampong Chhnang Province. She is a vegetable seller and pig breeder. Since her pig-breeding business is doing well, Mrs. Saophai P. wants to expand it so she decided to ask for a loan to buy more piglets and pig food.

Mrs. Saophai P. is 56 years old and a widow with three children, one of whom is a farmer while another one is a construction worker. The youngest child is enrolled in school. Previously, Mrs. Saophai P. had obtained a loan from AMK to start selling vegetable and she has fully paid it back.

loans.use: To buy more piglets and pig food to improve her standard of living.

loans.name: Muhabbat

texts.en:
Muhabbat T. is 36 years old. She is divorced and raising her two children alone. She lives in Shahrituz and sells kids' clothing in the central local market. She always offers only the best quality, trendy merchandise. Her inventory is always in high demand among women customers.

Muhabbat is very enterprising and confident. She has been in this business for 5 years. Currently, her turnover capital is about US$ 500. Her love for her children is what drives her forward from day to day and Muhabbat is doing all the best in order to ensure her children with a good education.

Today she is requesting a loan of 1000 Somoni (300 USD) with a term of 12 months to purchase new, more expensive clothing before the autumn season. We believe Muhabbat’s willingness to offer her customers greater value and a wider choice of merchandise, combined with her excellent service, will secure the successful growth of her business and guarantee good profits from sales. She hopes one day to have enough savings to fulfill her desire to open her own larger clothing store in the city of Shahrituz. Support this woman of much strength and courage to keep working!

loans.use: Purchasing new clothing for kids to increase her range of goods

loans.name: Sal

texts.en:
Mrs. Sal O., 38, makes brooms for sale from her house. She makes about 40 brooms per day and sells US$0.25 for one. She has been making and selling brooms for about eighteen years. With her long experience, she can earn approximately US$5.00 per day, while her husband, Mr. Phally Chon, 44, is car driver for a company. Sal has five children, two of whom are construction workers and another son is gasoline station staff, living in Kdol Donteav Commune in the Battambang Province.

Sal faces difficulty to attract her clients come to buy brooms from her house. To overcome this obstacle, she decided to seek a loan of US$1,200 to use for decorating house to make easier for making broom and also attract her customers. The remainder of loan is being used to add her capital for making brooms. The loan will improve the family's income through expanding her broom selling business.

loans.use: To use for decorating house to make easier for making brooms and also attract customers

loans.name: Silvia

texts.es:
La Señora Silvia, socia del Banco Comunal “Maria de Jesús II”, vive en la Región y Provincia de San Martín, distrito de Tarapoto. Se dedica a la confección de lencería y todo tipo de prendas para damas, caballeros y niños. Vive en la casa de su mamá en el Jr. Tarapoto Nº 120, lugar donde realiza sus trabajos de lencería para luego venderlas. Las prendas de vestir las trabaja en base a pedidos y sus clientes son amigos, familiares y personas que llegan gracias a la recomendación de sus clientes ya existentes a quienes ella los trata muy bien para mantenerlos y asegurar sus ventas.

Con este préstamo de S/. 800, el cual será cancelado en 06 meses, comprará hilos de diferentes colores, telas de diversos colores y variedades para la confección de todo tipo de prendas, elásticos, blondas, cierres y todo lo que se requiere en la realización de sus trabajos. Desea contar con un buen stock porque sabe que ya llegan las fiestas de fin de año y ahí es cuando le llegan muchos pedidos.

Silvia tiene  23 años de edad, vive con su esposo quien la apoya en sus metas y con su pequeña hija. Es una mujer entusiasta y emprendedora y su meta es la de superarse en la costura y contar con su taller implementado con máquinas industriales modernas.
texts.en:
Silvia is a member of the "Maria de Jesus II" Community Bank. She lives in San Martin region and province, Tarapoto district. She makes lingerie and clothing for women, men and children. She lives in her mother's house at Jiron Tarapoto, no. 120, where she makes and then sells lingerie. Silvia makes made-to-order clothing. Her clients are her friends, relatives and others who have heard about her business from existing clients. She treats all of her clients well to keep them satisfied and ensure her sales. With this loan of 800 soles [about US $275] -- which will be paid back in six months -- Silvia plans to purchase threads of various colors and fabrics of various colors and varieties to make all kinds of clothing. She also will buy elastic bands, lace, zippers and other items needed for making clothing. She would like to have an ample stock of these items because she expects to receive a lot of orders, as the end-of-year holidays will arrive soon. Silvia is 23 years old and lives with her husband, who supports her in her goals and with their young daughter. She is an enthusiastic and enterprising woman whose goals are to get better at sewing clothing and to equip her workshop with modern industrial sewing machines.

Translated from Spanish by Todd M. Anderson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of thread, fabric, elastic bands, zippers, etc.

loans.name: Janet

texts.es: Janet tiene 38 años, vive con su pareja y sus dos hijas Catiuska de 13 y Zait de 04. Vende ropa de forma ambulatoria en la ciudad de Puno, desde hace 5 años, ya que al terminar la secundaria y no tener las posibilidades de cursar estudios superiores, se dedicó de enteramente al negocio. La venta es buena, usualmente los sábados que es cuando hay feria en la ciudad de Puno, lo único complicado en su trabajo es el no poder estar todo el tiempo que ella quisiera con sus hijas, las cuales son su fuente de motivación y por las cuales trabaja día a día en busca de brindarles lo mejor. Este es su primer préstamo en Micro finanzas Prisma, siendo muy puntual en los pagos. Con el dinero viajará a las ciudades de Lima y Tacna a adquirir mayor cantidad de ropa para mejorar sus ingresos.
texts.en:
Janet is 38 years old and lives with her partner and their two daughters, Catiuska and Zait, respectively 13 and 4 years old. Janet is a street vendor and since five years she sells clothes in the city of Puno. She started selling clothes when she finished junior high school because she could not continue attending school. In general, business is good and Saturday's is the best day of the week, due to the Puno's weekly fair. The only complicated thing about her work, is that she can not be with her daughters as much time as she wanted. Her daughters are Janet's source of motivation and she works in order go give them better opportunities. This is Janet's first loan with Microfinanzas Prisma; she will be very punctual with the payments. With the money she obtains from the loan, she will travel to the cities of Lima and Tacna to buy more clothing and increase her revenues.

Translated from Spanish by Jimena Almendares Leistner, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To travel to the cities of Lima and Tacna to buy more clothing and increase her revenues

loans.name: Mr. Seik Kung Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Fourteen people who live in Kampao village in Takeo province make up a village bank loan with Mr. Seik K.  as its President. He is a gathers palm juice to process it into palm sugar or wine. His wife, Mrs. Kim Oun, is a farmer who owns a small piece of land to cultivate rice. Aside from the plantation, she is a pig breeder. Even though they try to work hard, they still earn less income to provide a better life for their family. In order to improve the living conditions, Mr. Seik K. decided to ask for a loan to buy more piglets for his wife's business and bamboos to be tied to the palm trees to make climbing easy for him when he gathers juice. He is a 36-year old father of four children, three of whom are enrolled in the local school while the youngest one is too young to work or study. 

This is a group loan consisting of mainly end-of-term loans. Twelve members have end-of-term loans and the rest of have monthly payment loans. The 12 members are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make their payments many months before the end of the loan term.

loans.use: To buy more piglets for his wife's business and bamboos to be tied to the palm trees to make climbing easy for him when he gathers juice.

loans.name: José Dolores

texts.es:
El caballero José Dolores U. desde hace dos años decidió poner su propia pulpería con el propósito de generar ingresos que le permitieran mejorar su nivel de vida y el de su familia en el municipio de Chichigalpa. Hoy en día ha logrado invertir en la pulpería habiéndola desarrollado en para esto se ha apoyado de los créditos brindados por Ceprodel ya que los ha invertido en la compra de los productos.

La razón por la que él ha acudido a Ceprodel es para obtener un crédito con el cual comprar los productos necesarios para la pulpería. Espera muy confiadamente que su crédito sea otorgado y de esta forma contribuir al desarrollo y mejoramiento de su pulpería que tanto requiere de su apoyo.
texts.en:
The gentleman José Dolores U. has owned his own convenience store for two years, in order to generate income in order to improve his and his family's quality of life in the municipality of Chichigalpa. Today he has managed to invest in the store, having been able to develop his store with the support of the credits offered by Ceprodel, an affiliate of Kiva. He has approached Ceprodel to obtain another loan in order to buy the necessary products for his store. He is waiting confidentially for his loan to be given and thusly contribute to the development and the improvement of his store, which greatly requires your support.

Translated from Spanish by Lois Parshley, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Compra de los productos de pulpería

loans.name: Marcos Antonio

texts.es: Don Marcos es un pequeño productor agricola que habita en la finca junto a su familia compuesta por 5 hijos y su esposa, 3 de sus hijos estudian y trabajan junto a su papá en tiempo libre, la esposa todos los dias garantiza la alimentacion de sus hijos y su marido, a la vez cria especies menores (gallina y cerdos) para aportar al sostenimiento del hogar.  El mayor sueño de don Marcos es asociarse en la construccion del trillo arrocero, para lo que solicita el credito.
texts.en:
Don Marcos is a small agricultural producer who lives on a farm with his family, which is comprised of five children and his wife. Three of his children study and work along with their father in their free time. His wife guarantees that her husband and kids are fed every day. She also raises small animals (chickens and pigs) to support their family. Don Marcos' biggest dream is to be associated with the construction of a rice thresher, which is why he's requesting the loan.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Investment in the construction of a rice thresher

loans.name: Mrs. Pao Uk Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan is for 16 people who all live in Krang Samroang village in Kampong Chhnang province. They will use the loan for various purposes. Mrs. Pao U., 43, is the village bank president. She and her husband, Mr. So Sreng, are farmers who own a piece of land where they cultivate vegetables. In this plantation, they have an obstacle because they do not have enough money for planting the field. Thus, Mrs. Pao U. decided to ask for a loan so they can grow vegetables to earn some income. She has five children, one of whom is a firewood seller while the others are enrolled in the local school. 

Thirteen members in this group loans have end-of-term (EoT) loans and the rest have monthly payment loans. Those with EoT loans are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term loans are AMK’s main product because they are the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. These loans allow borrowers to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To plant vegetables

loans.name: Udverte

texts.fr:
Née en 1970 à Porto-Novo, Capitale Administrative, D. Udverte réside  dans le 3e arrondissement de la ville de Porto-Novo. Udverte est mère d’un seul (01) enfant scolarisé. Udverte a pour activité principale la vente de farine d’amidon appelée localement « Tapioca » et de charbon. Pour diversifier ses sources de revenu, Udverte vend aussi de l’huile de palme et de l’alcool local «Sodabi». Udverte sollicite un crédit  pour renforcer ses activités afin d’avoir plus de revenus. 

 
La signification de ALIDé en langue locale du Bénin, le Fon, est « un chemin existe toujours pour les plus pauvres ». Le Bénin est un petit pays de l’Afrique de l’Ouest à coté du Nigeria où le PIB par habitant est à $1,500. ALIDé offre les prêts spéciaux de 0% d’intérêt aux personnes très vulnérables et elle est dans un groupe qui lance bientôt un programme de la micro-assurance santé pour les bénéficiaires de micro crédit.
texts.en:
Born in 1970 in Porto-Novo, the administrative capital of Bénin, Udverte D. lives in the third arrondissement of this city. She's the mother of one school-attending child. Her main business consists in selling cassava flour, known locally as tapioca, and charcoal. To diversify her sources of income, Udverte also sells palm oil and a local alcohol called "sodabi". She's seeking this loan to bolster her business, in order to increase her profits.

Alidé means “there is always a path for the poorest” in Benin’s local language of Fon. Benin is a small West African country located next to Nigeria and has a per capita GDP of $1,500. Alidé offers special loans to highly vulnerable people at an interest rate of 0%. It is part of a group that is soon launching a micro health insurance program.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy sacks of cassava flour and charcoal

loans.name: Rowena

texts.en:
Mrs. Rowena C. is 37 years old and lives at Punta Blanca, Oroquieta City. She has a common law husband who is a motor cab driver. They have been in a relationship for many years already but have not borne a child. She concentrates on earning for their daily needs and hopes that someday they will be blessed with at least one child.

She has opened a “sari-sari” store (general store) as another source of income. She got her capital from Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative, being a member since September 2008. Today, she is applying for PHP8,000 to buy additional goods for her sari-sari store and to repair their motorcycle. Her plan is to have a happy and contented family of her own.

loans.use: To buy additional goods for her sari-sari store

loans.name: Tumurbaatar

texts.en:
Tumurbaatar O. is 46, married and the father of three. All three children are attending elementary school. His family lives in a "ger" (a nomadic Mongolian tent) in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia.

In 1997, he started a wholesale meat business at the local market "Huchit shonhor". Tumurbaatar has an old Russian pick-up truck which he uses once every two or three months to pick up meat in Arhanghay, one of Mongolia's central provinces. He buys whole animals such as sheep, cows and horses with 4.5 million tugrugs ($1.00=1450 MNT) to re-sell for a higher price.

In 2008, his spouse, Enhtuya, joined him in his business. She rents a stall for 200,000 tugrugs at "Asait," one of the local food markets, to sell meat. Their working capital has now increased to 5.8 million tugrugs and their average monthly income is 8 million tugrugs. Tumurbaatar requests a loan to buy more whole animals to increase his business inventory.

loans.use: to buy more whole animals

loans.name: Badamtsetseg

texts.en: Badamtsetseg L., 45, is married and the mother of three. Her family lives in a "ger" (traditional nomadic tent) district on the plot of land she owns in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Her youngest two children are attending an elementary school. In 2001, she opened a booth to sell food products next to her little house. As a result of her businesses growth, her booth has developed into a grocery store. Her working capital is now 2 million tugrugs, average daily income is 100,000 tugrugs and average monthly profits from grocery store are 350,000 tugrugs. ($1 USD=1400 MNT). She works as a saleswoman at her store and her children help when she goes to the market to buy food. Badamtsetseg's husband, Vasil, has been working in the Czech Republic for the last four years, and sends $200 US home every month. It is common in Mongolia for people to go to the Czech Republic to find a better paying job. She has opened bank accounts for her children's future university tuition and deposits the money from her husband into them. Badamtsetseg also has another source of extra income. She rents a small house on the plot of land she owns for 50,000 tugrugs a month. With this loan, she will buy food products to increase her business inventory.

loans.use: To buy food products for her grocery store.

loans.name: Mahwish Muhammad Kamran Group

texts.en:
Mahwish baji is the wife of M. K. and has lived in a historical place, named Yadgar, of the city Lahore, Pakistan for the past 15 years. Her husband runs a construction supplies selling business. He takes orders from the building contractors and provide them with the supplies. He has 3 years of experience in this business.

Mahwish baji is a very good natured lady. She always supports her husband in his business. She takes care of his needs and his health all the time. She is the group leader of the mentioned ladies also. She is applying for a loan to buy construction supplies to complete the orders of customers so that he keeps his reputation in the eyes of customers.

Tayyaba baji wants a loan to buy a sewing machine for sewing clothes.

Shazia baji wants a loan to buy sports items (bats, balls) to sell.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy construction supplies to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To grow a very tasty ground nut commonly called "efio" (tiger nut)

loans.name: Akua

texts.en: Akua started her fish selling business eight years ago at Sefwi,  where she lives. She prepares and serves her customers with very tasty and good quality fish and because of that many customers buy from her stand. She is 42 years old and married, and has five children who are in school. She takes delivery of fishes from Yeji in the Brong Ahafo region. She wants to use the loan to buy more assorted fishes to make increased sales and income to support her children’s education and business growth. She would be grateful for the assistance.

loans.use: To buy more stock of smoked fishes

loans.name: Angelina

texts.en:
Angelina P. owns a small sari-sari store. She is 58 years old and has five children. She always wanted to make her business grow because her family depends on what she earns from her business. She started a small store in 2003 with PHP 5,000 capital. She started her business by buying goods and selling them in their village.

Now, she needs additional capital to sustain her store. She is asking for a loan of PHP 16,000 from Community Economic Ventures. The loan will surely help her increase her family's income.

 Her dream is to be able to expand in her business so that she will be able to support the education of her children.

loans.use: To purchase assorted groceries.

loans.name: Letty

texts.en:
Letty is the responsible housewife of Romy D.. They live in a rural place in Barangay Manamtam in Bambang, Nueva Vizcaya. They are blessed with eight children who are currently studying at the secondary and elementary level. Despite the hardships of life, Letty and her husband strive hard to earn a living to support the needs of their children, especially for their education.

The common source of their income is farming. They help each other to cultivate their farm by planting rice and vegetables. Letty sells the vegetables that they harvest in their village. She enjoys the business and wants to further improve the business so they can consistently support their children's education. Letty is requesting a loan of PHP 9,000 from Kive to use as additional business capital. Her business brings her family a good source of income and she hopes that it will grow and progress someday.

loans.use: Additional capital

loans.name: Brao

texts.en:
Brao L. is from the village of Luyong Bonbon, Opol Misamis Oriental. She is 35 years old. Brao is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Brao owns and operates a specialized retail stall. She is into fish vending and "alacarte" business. The main source of income for the business comes from selling seafood products including fish and shrimp in the local community. Brao has been engaged in her business for over 1 year and earns approximately 2,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Brao joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Brao is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Brao from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support the education of her children.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Dzigbodi Akuwa

texts.fr: D. Akuavi Dzigbodi est une femme âgée de 57 ans mariée et mère de 4 enfants. Elle habite à Franciscain un quartier de Lomé. Avec ce prêt, elle voudrait installer une cabine téléphonique dans sa boutique d'alimentation générale et acheter des cartes de recharge en vue de la revente afin d’augmenter son chiffre d’affaires. Avec son chiffre d’affaires, elle voudrait achever sa construction.
texts.en:
D. Akuavi Dzigbodi is a 57-year-old married woman and the mother of 4 children. She lives in Franciscain, a district of Lomé. With this loan, she would like to install a phone booth and buy mobile phone recharge cards to resell in order to increase her sales. With her sales, she would like to have some construction completed.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To install a telephone booth

loans.name: Alma

texts.en:
Alma D. is from the town of Plaridel. She is 33 years old. Alma is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Alma owns & operates a business venture in the services sector operating a service-based business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from providing hairdressing & beauty services to local community members. Alma has been engaged in her business for over 4 years and earns approximately 1,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Alma joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Alma has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase materials needed to provide service. Alma is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the 4th loan taken out by Alma from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of the borrower's family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Say
